Putnam's own position represents another attempt at overcoming the dilemma of objectivism and relativism. See, for example, Reason, pp. ixff. He criticizes both metaphysical realism and cultural relativism. He, too, fails, however, to overcome it because in his critique of the one standpoint he is forced to argue from the standpoint of the other, and conversely. It is tempting to compare the debate that is presently taking place in philosophy with the struggle that has been going on for a long time in the Christian religion. The same fate that befell faith in Scripture, when this canon of the Christian religion was understood in the context of history, now also befalls the trust in reason, as the ultimate authority of humanism. In both instances one sees fundamentalism pitted against relativism.

Ibid., p. 327: "As soon as a 'school' insulates itself from thinkers of another view, exclusivism overshadows the difference in position and an inner stifling which introduces a petty bourgeois mentality into the philosophical discussion becomes inevitable. Such a mentality leaves no room for reciprocal respect and for the awareness that each in his own way is working on a tremendous communal task. Sectarian exclusivism betrays itself, on the one hand, in its inability to use immanent criteria for criticizing philosophy of a different orientation and, on the other hand, in the incapacity to enrich or enlarge one's own thinking by themes on which those have reflected which do not belong to one's school... One does no longer understand that every philosophical critique must have a dialectical [elsewhere (Philosophia Reformata 6(1941), p. 20) Dooyeweerd speaks of 'dialogical'] nature in order to be fruitful... that is to say, the nature of discussing the problem in such a way that the critique on the other is, at the same time, a critique on oneself... The philosophical community of thought ought not to be abandoned even between schools which radically oppose each other in starting points."
